definitions.definition: in or into a position covering, touching or forming part of a surface

examples.text: a picture on a wall
There's a mark on your skirt.
the diagram on page 5
Put it down on the table.
He had been hit on the head.
She climbed on to the bed.
She was standing on one foot.
Try lying on your back.
Hang your coat on that hook.

definitions.definition: used to show a means of transport

examples.text: He was on the plane from New York.
to travel on the bus/tube/coach
I came on my bike.
a woman on horseback

definitions.definition: by means of something; using something

examples.text: She played a tune on her guitar.
The information is available on the internet.
We spoke on the phone.
What's on TV?
The programme's on Channel 4.

definitions.definition: used to show a day or date

examples.text: He came on Sunday.
We meet on Tuesdays.
on May the first/the first of May
on the evening of May the first
on one occasion
on your birthday

definitions.definition: used to describe an activity or a state

examples.text: to be on business/holiday/vacation
The book is currently on loan.
on the left/right
He turned his back on us.
a town on the coast
a house on the Thames
We lived on an estate.

definitions.definition: used to show the basis or reason for something

examples.text: a story based on fact
On their advice I applied for the job.
On arriving home I discovered they had gone.
Please report to reception on arrival.
There was a letter waiting for him on his return.
a book on South Africa
She tested us on irregular verbs.

definitions.definition: used to show that somebody belongs to a group or an organization

examples.text: to be on the committee/staff/jury/panel
Whose side are you on *(= which of two or more different views do you support)*?

definitions.definition: eating or drinking something; using a drug or a medicine regularly

examples.text: He lived on a diet of junk food.
The doctor put me on antibiotics.
to live on a pension/a student grant
to be on a low wage
You can't feed a family on £50 a week.
Drinks are **on me** *(= I am paying)*.

definitions.definition: used when giving a phone number

examples.text: You can get me on 020 7946 0887.
She's on extension 2401.

definitions.definition: used with some nouns or adjectives to say who or what is affected by something

examples.text: a ban on smoking
He's hard on his kids.
Go easy on the mayo! *(= do not take/give me too much)*

definitions.definition: being carried by somebody; in the possession of somebody

examples.text: Have you got any money on you?
Sales are up on last year.

wordOrigin: Old English on, an, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch aan and German an, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek ana.
